snippet: Some, like Whole Foods and the NorthWestern Corporation, have said how much more money their C.E.O.s are paid than their employees in advance of an S.E.C. ruling on Wednesday.
abstract: Some publicly held companies, including Whole Foods and Noble Energy, had started reporting difference between their top executives' pay and their workers' long before Securities and Exchange Commission issued rule requiring information be made public; companies revealing information preemptively see disclosure as confirmation of their commitment to addressing issues of income inequality and fair labor practices.
lead_paragraph: Some, like Whole Foods and the NorthWestern Corporation, have said how much more money their C.E.O.s are paid than their employees in advance of an S.E.C. ruling on Wednesday.
